projects.name: Smiðja Parliamentary Offices

stakeholders.name: Framkvæmdasýslan - Ríkiseignir
stakeholders.contribution: State property management and project owner

projects.circularity_qualification: 80% material circularity with 100% local Icelandic stone - reused basalt from hospital demolition, reopened abandoned quarry, and 100% stone offcut upcycling to terrazzo floors.

circular_features.description: Basalt stone from Landspítali hospital demolition used for facade and interior
Red stone from reopened abandoned local quarry
Stone offcuts from facade cutting reused as decorative terrazzo-effect flooring in 6 meeting rooms
Classic Icelandic chairs from Alþingi's existing collection restored and reused
Reclaimed doors sourced from recycling centers
Rooftop art installation using aluminum production byproduct ('red thread')
100% locally sourced Icelandic stone, eliminating import emissions

circularity_rate.methodology: Material reuse assessment from Nordic LCA study

co2_reduction.note: LCA completed via One Click LCA but specific reduction not published. Expected better than benchmark (9.1 kg CO2e/m²/year for typical offices)

awards.name: Iceland Design Awards - Place of the Year
EU Prize for Contemporary Architecture - Mies van der Rohe Award

build_for_longterm.note: High-quality materials, parliament building designed for 100+ year lifespan

build_efficiently.note: 80% material reuse, stone offcut upcycling, local sourcing

build_with_right_materials.note: 100% local Icelandic stone, natural materials, LCA-informed choices

primary.title: Nordic Best Practice Catalogue - Smiðja LCA Entry
Nordic Best Practice Catalogue for Building LCA Cases

secondary.title: Scandinavian Mind Interview - Stone Reuse Philosophy

narrative.driver: Parliament building to symbolize Iceland's commitment to sustainability using local resources
narrative.approach: All stone sourced from Iceland - either reclaimed from hospital demolition or from reopened abandoned quarry. 100% stone offcuts upcycled into meeting room floors. Design philosophy based on geological strata revealed during archaeological excavation on site.
narrative.challenges: Icelandic basalt is brittle (only 30% yield when cutting). LCA tools lack factors for Icelandic stone, defaulting to Norwegian references. Pushback from engineers preferring imported stone.
narrative.lessons_learned: Local stone reuse can achieve 80% circularity even in challenging geological contexts. Design integration of waste streams (offcuts→floors) maximizes material value.

projects.name: Umhverfisstofnun Office Renovation
projects.circularity_qualification: First Nordic Swan certified renovation in ALL Nordic countries (Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Iceland) - 94.4% waste sorting (vs 70% EU requirement), 40% energy savings from HVAC, 85% preservation, aluminum frames reused in place.

circular_features.description: Aluminum window and door frames reused in place - cleaned and resealed rather than replaced
Cork tiles preserved from original interior
94.4% construction waste sorting rate - far exceeding 70% EU requirement
All paints and sealants Nordic Swan certified - no GHS-classified hazardous substances

co2_reduction.note: ~70-80% less than demolition + new build (estimated). 40% energy savings from HVAC upgrades.

certifications.name: Nordic Swan Ecolabel
certifications.note: First Nordic Swan certified renovation in all Nordic countries

build_efficiently.note: 94.4% waste sorting, aluminum frame reuse, cork preservation

build_with_right_materials.note: All materials Nordic Swan certified, low-VOC, no hazardous substances

primary.title: Svanurinn Press Release - First Nordic Swan Renovation

secondary.title: Byggjum Grænni Framtíð - Swan Certification Guide

narrative.driver: Environment Agency wanted to demonstrate sustainability leadership by achieving first Nordic Swan renovation certification in Nordics
narrative.approach: Aggressive material preservation strategy - aluminum frames reused in place, cork tiles preserved. All new materials Nordic Swan certified. 94.4% waste sorting achieved through selective dismantling and pre-demolition mapping.
narrative.challenges: Renovation requires meeting both preservation goals and stringent Nordic Swan chemical/material requirements. Risk assessment needed for reused materials (asbestos, PCBs, heavy metals testing).
narrative.lessons_learned: Early integration of Nordic Swan criteria from design phase is critical. Digital material logging (O20 requirement) enables long-term tracking. Public sector renovation can achieve higher circularity than many new builds.

projects.name: Háteigsvegur 59 Social Housing

stakeholders.name: SSJ Steinsmiðja / Grafa og grjót
stakeholders.contribution: Stone tiles donated from Alþingi Smiðja project

projects.circularity_qualification: 53% CO2 reduction with 20% reused/surplus materials - social housing demonstrating circular construction is achievable at conventional cost with Yakisugi cladding and low-carbon concrete.

circular_features.description: Berglind Plús low-carbon concrete with crushed surplus stone tiles as aggregate
circular_features.donor_source: Surplus stone tiles from construction projects

circular_features.description: Composite windows made from 6 reclaimed windows + 7 new units assembled together
Exterior cladding from surplus/packaging timber, Yakisugi/Shou Sugi Ban heat-treated (no chemical impregnation)
Interior stone tiles reused from Alþingi Smiðja parliament project
Reclaimed beech sports parquet flooring
Interior partition walls made from flexible plywood previously used as formwork

circularity_rate.methodology: Percentage of building materials that are reused or surplus

co2_reduction.methodology: vs reference building, verified by VSÓ LCA at completion
co2_reduction.notes: Initial target 30%, achieved 53%. Some sources report up to 59%.

concrete_co2_reduction.methodology: Berglind Plús with recycled aggregate vs conventional

cost.note: Within conventional cost framework despite circular approach. Yakisugi cladding cheaper than corrugated metal.

awards.name: EU Prize for Contemporary Architecture - Mies van der Rohe Award

build_for_longterm.note: High-quality durable materials, Yakisugi treatment extends cladding life

build_with_right_materials.note: 53% CO2 reduction, recycled aggregate concrete, local donor sources, chemical-free Yakisugi

primary.title: Reykjavík City - Opening Announcement (53% CO2 reduction)
BM Vallá - Sustainable Housing Case Study

secondary.title: Grænni byggð - Græna skóflan Project Page

narrative.driver: Félagsbústaðir wanted to demonstrate that circular construction is achievable within conventional cost/time frameworks for social housing
narrative.approach: LCA+LCC integrated from design phase. Systematic sourcing of surplus/donated materials from local partners (Húsasmiðjan, Byko, Gluggagerðin). Low-carbon concrete with recycled aggregate. Yakisugi heat treatment as chemical-free cladding solution.
narrative.challenges: Iterative material sourcing required flexibility - materials found during construction, not specified in advance. Some sources report different CO2 reduction figures (30%/40%/50%/53%/59%) due to different baselines.
narrative.lessons_learned: Circular approach achievable at conventional cost when partnerships are established. Yakisugi cladding proved cheaper than corrugated metal. Stone material flows between projects (Smiðja → H59) demonstrate emerging Icelandic circular ecosystem.

projects.name: Stöng Viking Ruins Shelter

stakeholders.name: Framkvæmdasýslan - Ríkiseignir
stakeholders.contribution: State project management on behalf of Minjastofnun

building.note: ArchDaily states 385 m², Arquitectura Viva states 400 m²

project_type.description: 1957 timber shelter preserved and transformed - first heritage site in Iceland designed with sustainability focus
project_type.preservation_note: Estimated 60-75% original structure retained based on research documentation

projects.circularity_qualification: First heritage site in Iceland designed with sustainability focus: 1957 timber shelter preserved and transformed with untreated larch cladding and translucent polycarbonate roof.

circular_features.description: 1957 timber load-bearing frame retained and reinforced rather than demolished

quantity.note: No numerical preservation percentage published, but multiple sources confirm 'burðarvirkið frá 1957' (1957 load-bearing structure) is reused

circular_features.description: Untreated larch re-cladding applied to preserved 1957 structure
Translucent corrugated polycarbonate roof (Brett Martin) replacing former corrugated metal - allows natural light and airflow
Steel connectors and reinforcement to strengthen existing timber frame

circularity_rate.note: Estimated 60-75% original structure retained. No formal circularity assessment published but framed as 'in the spirit of sustainability and reuse of building material' (Minjastofnun)

co2_reduction.note: No formal LCA. Estimated 50-100 tonnes CO2 equivalent savings from structure reuse vs new construction based on preservation extent.

awards.name: EU Prize for Contemporary Architecture - Mies van der Rohe Award

programs: Landsáætlun um uppbyggingu innviða til verndar náttúru og menningarsögulegum minjum

build_nothing_new.note: 1957 shelter preserved and reused rather than demolished

build_for_longterm.note: Heritage protection, structural reinforcement extends lifespan

build_efficiently.note: Structure reuse evident but no quantified metrics

build_with_right_materials.note: Untreated larch is sustainable choice, but no LCA documentation

data_completeness.upgrade_path: Contact Minjastofnun or SP(R)INT STUDIO for technical documentation

narrative.driver: Minjastofnun needed to protect the 11th-century Viking ruins from erosion while improving visitor access. Decision was made to preserve and transform the 1957 shelter rather than build entirely new.
narrative.approach: Design competition resulted in SP(R)INT STUDIO's winning concept that treats the 1957 shelter as 'an artifact worth conserving in its own right'. Structure retained and reinforced with untreated larch cladding and translucent polycarbonate roof allowing natural light.
challenges: Protecting fragile archaeological remains while improving accessibility
Balancing modern intervention with heritage preservation
narrative.lessons_learned: Heritage preservation and material reuse can be combined - protecting both ancient ruins AND the protective structures built to house them. Described as 'first heritage site in Iceland to be designed with a focus on environmental and social sustainability'.
